intro: Poacynum sarmatiense, commonly known as the Sarmatian milkweed, is a perennial shrub native to the Caucasus region. It belongs to the family Apocynaceae and is characterized by its woody stems and showy, tubular flowers. The plant produces a milky sap that is toxic, containing cardiac glycosides. Its leaves are typically narrow and lance-shaped, and it thrives in rocky or arid environments. Poacynum sarmatiense is adapted to harsh climates and plays a role in supporting local pollinators.
